key_insight: eMOSAIC combines multimodal input representations with per-instance, per-modality out-of-distribution (OOD) uncertainty estimates to substantially improve binding-affinity predictions for compounds that act on multiple proteins (polypharmacology).
problem_solved: Predictive models for binding affinity struggle with samples outside training distributions and with compounds that interact with many targets; they lack calibrated, modality-specific uncertainty estimates needed to prioritize reliable predictions in drug discovery.
method: Fuse multimodal data (molecular structures, protein sequences/structures, and experimental bioactivity/context) into a joint representation for affinity prediction.
Compute individual OOD and aleatoric/epistemic uncertainty estimates per modality and per sample, then aggregate these to produce calibrated confidence scores.
Use uncertainty-aware training and evaluation (OOD detection + calibration) to downweight or flag low-confidence predictions, improving real-world decision-making for polypharmacology tasks.
impact: Provides AI/ML practitioners a practical way to obtain trustworthy affinity predictions and actionable confidence estimates, enabling better prioritization of experiments and safer candidate selection in drug discovery pipelines.
visual_elements: Schematic: multimodal inputs (molecule, protein, assay/context) → eMOSAIC model → per-modality uncertainty outputs + final affinity prediction
Calibration/OOD plot: reliability diagrams or ROC for OOD detection comparing eMOSAIC vs baselines
Network/heatmap: drug-target polypharmacology map with prediction confidence overlay to show high-confidence multi-target predictions
Bar chart: performance gains (RMSE, AUPR, calibration error) and reduction of false positives on OOD examples
paper_title: Multimodal out-of-distribution individual uncertainty quantification enhances binding affinity prediction for polypharmacology
paper_authors: Amitesh Badkul, Li Xie, Shuo Zhang, Lei Xie
